body: I think the problem was introduced in #2501 since we dont say that `int`/`float` are `IsHandledSpeciallyByNUnit` then we will just hash them and I guess that the hashcode for `42` is different from that of `42f`.

We should probably add `|| memberType == typeof(object)`:

https://github.com/nunit/nunit/blob/e465d6966971cdcdd7859439902707e2c56414cb/src/NUnitFramework/framework/Constraints/UniqueItemsConstraint.cs#L79-L83
@simarust Thanks for reporting this. Are you interested in contributing a fix? I think it would be as simple as adding the check I mentioned, plus adding the test you've written above.
Why did it "work" before? Are we changing the semantics here?

Yes. I think Mikkel spotted the semantic change we made. If `memberType == typeof(object)`, we go ahead with the fast hashtable code which does not use NUnit equality. We should put that under test too. Alternately, we could add the check to `IsHandledSpeciallyByNUnit`, if you'd say `System.Object` is specially handled by NUnit.
We have the same problem with nonsealed classes and interfaces in general, so we could also be on the safe side and check that the type is nonvirtual or sealed.

@jnm2 Actually, it's Numberic types that are handled specially, not object. We have a method (I'm not looking at the code right now, but it's called in NUnitEqualityComparer) that tests for our definition of numeric.

@CharliePoole That is why I lean toward not putting the check in `IsHandledSpeciallyByNUnit` but rather against the `memberType` variable. It's the collection element type which is System.Object, not the type of the instances themselves.
So you're basically saying that if the member type is object, it could be anything! That's right of course. Let's hope it doesn't happen often. :smile:

`new IConvertible[] { 1, 1f }` leaves us in the same boat as `new object[] { 1, 1f }` too. What do you think about requiring the element type to be nonvirtual or sealed in order to take the fast path, then cautiously proceeding back from there if adjustments are needed? That way we're completely safe by default.

Alright: I'm removing <kbd>good first issue</kbd> because I want to see comprehensive tests proving that NUnit equality is used when the element type is virtual and unsealed. @mikkelbu Would you like this one?
Sure. I can take a look at it.
@mikkelbu have you made any progress on this? It is in the 3.10 milestone and assigned to you. I would like to get 3.10 out soon, so I am triaging the issues remaining in the milestone.
